history.textHistory: Chenard & Walcker Sport achieved a historic victory in the very first '24 Hours of Le Mans' race. The crew, consisting of André Lagache and René Léonard, covered over 2,200 km in 24 hours — a remarkable success for a debut.
The Chenard & Walcker Sport featured a 2-liter 4-cylinder engine with overhead valves, giving it superior reliability and speed over its competitors.
In addition to the winning car, the second-place finish also went to a Chenard & Walcker vehicle — highlighting the brand’s dominance in the 1923 race.
The victory of Chenard & Walcker became a source of national pride for France and demonstrated that the country could compete with British and German manufacturers on the track.
Despite their success, Chenard & Walcker did not become a regular contender at Le Mans. However, their 1923 win remains a landmark moment in motorsport history.
